title: Introducing CORITheme
Authors and Citation
text: Meongsu Lee. Author, maintainer. Harsh Josh. Author. Matt Zdun. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Lee M, Josh H, Zdun M (2022). CORITheme: Package (One Line, Title Case). R package version 0.0.0.9000.
code: @Manual{,   title = {CORITheme: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)},   author = {Meongsu Lee and Harsh Josh and Matt Zdun},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000}, }

what: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Welcome CORITheme package! goal make process creating publication-ready graphics charts easy possible. ’s start.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: can install development version CORITheme GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("muwizayeon/CORITheme") library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(CORITheme)

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Like line graphs, bar charts can show trends data quite effectively. However, bar charts particularly useful (especially popular) ability allow audiences make comparisons quickly efficiently (example, one category twice large another category).

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: ’s simplest type bar chart. just one group visualized multiple categories. people picture thinking bar charts. example, ’s population diffrent races across United States America. Notice horizontal format bars. accomplished attaching coord_flip() function plot code (seen ). Use horizontal bars items visualize labels longer side appear messy squished written along bottom plot. Tip: theme also works vertical bars; simply omit coord_flip() function.
code: #Start off with population data from the U.S. Census Bureau's ACS data(upr) upr <- upre[,-c(1)]  ggplot(upr,aes(y=race, x=population)) +     geom_text(x = 0,aes(label = race),hjust=0,vjust=-2,size=3) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity",width=0.5, fill = "#01835D")+     theme_cori() + theme_cori_horizontal_bars() +   labs(title = "U.S. population by race",      subtitle = 'All estimates are across 2014.',      x="\nPopulation")

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: beauty bar charts shines using one group. chart format allows simple comparisons humans can perceive quickly. ’s example dodge chart (one compares two groups side--side). user can easily compare different unemployment levels top five rural counties highest unemployment levels. Tip: theme quite flexible. x-axis can support type categorical variable, whether geographic, race time data. Similar dodge charts stacked charts groups stacked instead next . ’s example comparing Asian Hispanic populations various rural communities. Tip: added clarity greater sense data, package allows add horizontal trend line average. Another interesting way visualize comparisons two groups use population pyramid. core, simply two bar charts rotated positioned side--side. following example compares share individuals high-speed internet Jefferson County, Alabama, time, broken race. Tip: Use graph format compare two groups time. usually used comparing men women, works well categories. Tip: Note time variable (x variable) must factor.
code:
#  Rural counties with the highest number
of unemployed people data(rcu) rcu <- rcu[,-c(1)] rcu$year <- as.factor(rcu$year)  rcu %>%     ggplot() +      aes(x=st_cnty, y=tot_pop, fill=year) +      geom_bar(position="dodge", stat="identity", width = 0.7) +      # geom_text(x=10000, y=0, aes(label="Persons")) +     cori_legend(title="Rural Counties") +     labs(title="Rural counties with the highest number
of unemployed people",          subtitle="Pulaski, MO saw the highest number of unemployed
people in both 2014 and 2019.",          caption="Source: U.S. Census Bureau",          y="Population"          ) +     scale_fill_cori(palette = "ctg2gn", discrete = TRUE) +     theme_cori(base_font_size = 14) #Start off with population data from the U.S. Census Bureau's ACS data(pbra) pbra <- pbra[,-c(1)]  ggplot(pbra, aes(x=county, y=population, fill=race)) +      geom_bar(stat='identity') +     labs(title = "Asian and Hispanic populations
in rural communities",          subtitle = 'All estimates are across 2019.',          x="Year",           y='Population') +      theme_cori() +      scale_fill_cori(palette='ctg2gn') + #Use the color palette for the two greens     cori_legend() #Start with data on high speed internet access in Jefferson County Alabama data(ias) ias <- ias[,-c(1)]  ggplot(internet_access_sample_data, aes(x=as.factor(year), y=percent_high_speed_internet, fill=race)) +      geom_bar(data = subset(internet_access_sample_data, race=="black"), stat = "identity") +     geom_bar(data = subset(internet_access_sample_data, race=="white"), stat = "identity", aes(y=-percent_high_speed_internet)) +      coord_flip() +     labs(title = "Percent with high-speed internet
in Jefferson County, AL",          subtitle = 'High-speed internet rates among White individuals were
almost double what they were among Black individuals.',           x="Year",            y='
Percent with high-speed internet') +     theme_cori() +      scale_fill_cori(palette='ctg2gn') +      cori_legend()

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: three groups, bar charts can help put magnitude different variables perspective. ’s example visualizing multiple racial categories across two different years. Tip: Make use several colors CORI custom palettes. following palettes helpful creating different bar charts: * ctg2gn: emerald mint * ctg2or: orange light orange * ctg2pu: purple light purple * ctg2bu: blue light blue * ctg7: emerald, mint, gold, orange, blue, purple blue
code: #Start with data on for the United States Population by Year data(upr) upr <- upr[,-c(1)]  ggplot(upr, aes(fill=race, y=x, x=year)) +    geom_bar(position="dodge", stat="identity",width = 0.5) +   scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(unique(upr$year)))+   scale_fill_cori_seven_race()+   theme_grouped_barchart() +   labs(title = "U.S. population by race",        subtitle = 'All estimates are across 2014 and 2019.\n\n',        x="Year's",        y='Population in Number')

A ggplot2 legend formatted in the Center on Rural Innovation (CORI) style — cori_legend
text: title title name legend, default "" base_font_size font size legend, default 14 vjust adjust vertical position

what: Return function to interpolate a cori color palette — cori_pal
title: Return function to interpolate a cori color palette — cori_pal
text: Return function interpolate cori color palette

title: Return function to interpolate a cori color palette — cori_pal
Return function to interpolate a cori color palette — cori_pal
text: palette Character name palette cori_palettes reverse Boolean indicating whether palette reversed ... Additional arguments pass colorRampPalette()

title: Return function to interpolate a cori color palette — cori_pal
code: cori_pal("ctg7") #> function (n)  #> { #>     x <- ramp(seq.int(0, 1, length.out = n)) #>     if (ncol(x) == 4L)  #>         rgb(x[, 1L], x[, 2L], x[, 3L], x[, 4L], maxColorValue = 255) #>     else rgb(x[, 1L], x[, 2L], x[, 3L], maxColorValue = 255) #> } #> <bytecode: 0x560d09ab0c70> #> <environment: 0x560d09ab3958>
